estimation_measure: Human extinction by 2100 as a result of “the single biggest natural pandemic”
other_notes: This is the median. Beard et al.'s appendix says "Note that for these predictions no time frame was given." I think that that's incorrect, based on phrasings in the original source, but I'm not certain.

estimation_measure: Existential catastrophe from “‘naturally’ arising pandemics” by 2120
Human extinction by 2100 as a result of “single biggest engineered pandemic”
other_notes: This is the median. Beard et al.'s appendix says "Note that for these predictions no time frame was given." I think that that's incorrect, based on phrasings in the original source, but I'm not certain.

estimation_measure: The annual probability of an existential catastrophe arising from a global pandemic
other_notes: The fact that there's a separate estimate from the same source for biowarfare and bioterrorism suggests to me that  this is meant to be an estimate of the risk from a natural pandemic only. But I'm not sure. This might also include "accidental" release of a bioengineered pathogen.
source: Millett, P., & Snyder-Beattie, A. (2017). Existential risk and cost-effective biosecurity. Health security, 15(4), 373-383. https://doi.org/10.1089/hs.2017.0028

estimation_measure: The annual probability of an existential catastrophe arising from biowarfare or bioterrorism
source: Millett, P., & Snyder-Beattie, A. (2017). Existential risk and cost-effective biosecurity. Health security, 15(4), 373-383. https://doi.org/10.1089/hs.2017.0028

estimation_measure: "Infinite impact" from a global pandemic within the next 100 years, which "refers to the state where civilization collapses and does not recover, or a situation where all human life ends" (according to Beard et al.)
other_notes: The fact that there's a separate estimate from the same source for "synthetic biology" suggests to me that this is meant to be an estimate of the risk from a natural pandemic only.
source: Pamlin, D. & Armstrong, S. (2015). Global Challenges: 12 Risks that Threaten Human Civilisation, Global Challenges Foundation.

estimation_measure: "Infinite impact" from "synthetic biology" within the next 100 years, which "refers to the state where civilization collapses and does not recover, or a situation where all human life ends" (according to Beard et al.)
source: Pamlin, D. & Armstrong, S. (2015). Global Challenges: 12 Risks that Threaten Human Civilisation, Global Challenges Foundation.

estimation_measure: Extinction risk from engineered pandemics over the coming 100 years
other_notes: This was a direct response to Ord's estimate, although this estimate is of extinction risk rather than existential risk. "These estimates should not be taken very seriously. I do not believe we have enough information to make sensible quantitative estimates about these eventualities. Nevertheless, I present my estimates largely in order to illustrate the extent of my disagreement with Ord’s estimates, and to illustrate the key considerations I examine in order to arrive at an estimate." In comments on the source, Will Bradshaw critiques some of the inputs to this estimate.
source: Critical Review of 'The Precipice': A Reassessment of the Risks of AI and Pandemics

estimation_measure: Aggregate estimate of biorisk's contribution to total x-risk by 2120 (very naive geometric mean, quickly and roughly extrapolating each estimate above into "contribution to total x-risk by 2120")
